speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges Mercutio to leave because the hot weather makes people irritable and the Capulets are out, so a fight is likely if they meet.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio compares Benvolio to a man who brags about his sword in a tavern but picks fights over nothing after a drink. 'Claps me' means 'slaps down,' 'drawer' is a bartender.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks if he really seems like such a person.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio insists Benvolio is as quick-tempered as anyone in Italy, easily provoked and quick to anger.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks what he would quarrel about.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio lists absurd reasons Benvolio would fight: over beard hair, nut-cracking (mocking his hazel eyes), coughing, or a tailor’s fashion choices. 'Doublet' is a jacket, 'riband' a ribbon. He concludes Benvolio’s head is as full of quarrels and as addled (confused) as an egg is full of meat (yolk).

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio jokes that if he were as quarrelsome as Mercutio, anyone could buy permanent ownership of his life for a short time—meaning he’d be killed quickly. 'Fee simple' means absolute ownership.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mocks Benvolio’s legal term 'fee simple' as silly, then Tybalt enters.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio warns that the Capulets are approaching.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio dismisses the danger, saying he doesn’t care.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt tells his companions to stay near, then greets the others with 'good-den' (good evening) and asks to speak with one of them.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio挑衅地回应，说如果只跟一个人说一句话，那就再加点别的，比如一句话加一拳。

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt says he’s ready to fight if given a reason.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio sarcastically asks if Tybalt can’t find a reason without being given one.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt says Mercutio associates with Romeo, using 'consortest' which can mean 'keep company with.'

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio pretends to take 'consort' as meaning a group of musicians, threatens discord, and brandishes his sword ('fiddlestick'), saying it will make Tybalt dance. 'Zounds' is a mild oath.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges them to move to a private place to discuss their grievances calmly or to leave, since they are in a public space where everyone is watching. This sets the scene for the coming conflict and shows his role as a peacemaker.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio defiantly says that eyes are meant to look, so let them stare; he refuses to move for anyone's convenience. His stubbornness highlights his hot-headed nature and disregard for public opinion.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt sarcastically wishes peace upon Mercutio and then notes that Romeo, the person he is looking for, has arrived.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mocks Tybalt, saying he would be hanged if Romeo wears Tybalt's livery (uniform), meaning Romeo is not his servant. He sarcastically suggests Tybalt go to a dueling field and Romeo will follow as his 'man' in that sense. This insults Tybalt's pride and challenges his claim over Romeo.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt tells Romeo that the only term his love for him allows is 'villain,' a deep insult questioning Romeo's honor. This directly provokes a duel.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo responds that he has reasons to love Tybalt which excuse the anger such a greeting would normally provoke; he says he is no villain and bids farewell, implying Tybalt does not truly know him. This reflects Romeo's secret marriage to Juliet making Tybalt his kinsman.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt dismisses Romeo's words as no excuse for the offenses he believes Romeo has committed, and commands him to turn and draw his sword.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo insists he never harmed Tybalt and loves him more than Tybalt can understand until he knows the reason; he says he values the Capulet name as dearly as his own and urges Tybalt to be satisfied. This further hints at his secret marriage without revealing it.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio exclaims in disgust at Romeo's calm, dishonorable submission. He draws his sword, saying 'Alla stoccata' (a fencing thrust) wins the day, and calls Tybalt a rat-catcher (mocking his name) and challenges him to fight.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt asks what Mercutio wants with him, playing along with the confrontation.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio, calling Tybalt 'Good King of Cats' (mocking 'Tybalt' from a cat in folklore), says he wants one of his nine lives, which he will boldly take, and depending on how Tybalt treats him later, he will dry-beat (beat without drawing blood) the other eight. He dares Tybalt to draw his sword quickly or he will strike him before it is out.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt draws his sword and says he is ready for Mercutio, accepting the challenge.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo urges Mercutio to put his sword away, trying to prevent the fight.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio ignores Romeo and challenges Tybalt with 'your passado' (a forward fencing thrust), and they begin fighting.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo calls on Benvolio to help beat down their swords, shame the gentlemen for this outrage, and reminds them the Prince has forbidden fighting in Verona's streets. He cries for them to stop as Tybalt and his followers exit.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio reveals he is wounded, curses both the Montague and Capulet houses with a plague, says he is done for ('sped'), and asks if Tybalt got away unharmed. This marks the turning point where Mercutio's death escalates the tragedy.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks if Mercutio is injured.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio downplays his wound as a scratch but says it is enough to be serious; he calls for his page to fetch a surgeon. 'Marry' is a mild oath.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo tries to reassure Mercutio that the injury cannot be too bad.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio jests grimly that his wound is not very deep or wide, but enough to kill him; 'grave' puns on serious and burial place. He says he is done for ('peppered') and curses both the Montague and Capulet houses. He blames Romeo for coming between them in the fight. 'Zounds' is an oath; 'by the book of arithmetic' mocks Tybalt's precise, formal dueling style.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo explains that he intervened with good intentions.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio asks Benvolio to help him inside before he faints, repeats his curse on both houses, and says they have turned him into food for worms (i.e., killed him).

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo reflects that Mercutio, a close friend and relative of the Prince, was mortally wounded for his sake, and his own reputation has been damaged by Tybalt’s insult. He laments that his love for Juliet has made him soft and less courageous.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio announces that Mercutio is dead and that his noble spirit has risen to the sky too soon.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo declares that this day’s tragic fate will affect more days to come; this is only the start of sorrows that others will finish.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio warns that Tybalt is returning angrily.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo, seeing Tybalt return after killing Mercutio, renounces gentle mercy and calls for furious rage to guide him. He demands Tybalt take back the insult 'villain,' saying Mercutio’s soul is waiting for Tybalt’s to join it, so one or both of them must die.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt calls Romeo a wretched boy who kept company with Mercutio and says he will join him in death.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says their fight will decide that outcome.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges Romeo to flee because the citizens are alerted and Tybalt is dead; he warns that the Prince will sentence him to death if caught.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo exclaims that he is the plaything of bad luck.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks why Romeo is still lingering.

speaker: FIRST CITIZEN
content: The First Citizen asks which way Tybalt, the murderer of Mercutio, ran. This shows the immediate chaos and pursuit after the fight.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio simply states that Tybalt lies dead here, pointing out the body.

speaker: FIRST CITIZEN
content: The citizen orders someone to come with him in the Prince’s name, asserting authority to arrest the offender.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince demands to know who started the fight, seeking the instigators of the brawl.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio tells the Prince he can explain the whole unfortunate event: Tybalt lies slain by Romeo, who killed Mercutio.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet mourns Tybalt as her cousin and nephew, then demands the Prince, as a just ruler, require a Montague’s death in return for Tybalt’s blood.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince asks Benvolio to name who began the bloody fight.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio recounts the events: Romeo tried to calm Tybalt, but Tybalt, ignoring peace, fought Mercutio. Romeo intervened, but Tybalt under Romeo’s arm fatally stabbed Mercutio, then fled and later returned to fight Romeo, who killed Tybalt and fled. Benvolio swears this is true.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet claims Benvolio is biased as a Montague relative and lies; she says many Montagues fought but only one died, and demands Romeo’s execution for killing Tybalt.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince notes Romeo killed Tybalt, and Tybalt killed Mercutio, then asks who owes the price for Mercutio’s death.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague argues Romeo was Mercutio’s friend and his action only carried out what the law would have done—executed Tybalt.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince exiles Romeo immediately, saying he too has suffered from their feud (Mercutio was his kinsman), fines both families heavily, and warns that mercy to killers only leads to more murder.
